description: Bridge the gap between Object-Oriented Programming and Relational Databases.

slides.title: What is an ORM? üåâ
slides.content:
# Object-Relational Mapping

A technique that lets you query and manipulate data from a database using an object-oriented paradigm.

Instead of SQL `SELECT * FROM users`, you do `User.findAll()`.

slides.title: Why use an ORM? ü§î
slides.content:
# Productivity üöÄ

- **Write less code:** No redundant SQL queries.
- **Security:** Automatic SQL injection protection.
- **Maintainability:** Code is cleaner and easier to read.
- **Portability:** Switch databases (e.g., MySQL to Postgres) easily.

slides.title: Mapping objects to Tables
slides.content:
# The Correspondence ‚úâÔ∏è

- **Class** (e.g., `class User`) maps to **Table** (`users`).
- **Instance** (`new User()`) maps to **Row**.
- **Property** (`user.name`) maps to **Column**.

slides.title: CRUD Operations
slides.content:
# Magic Methods ‚ú®

Most ORMs provide standard methods:
- `save()` / `create()`
- `find()` / `get()`
- `update()`
- `delete()` / `destroy()`

slides.title: Lazy vs Eager Loading
slides.content:
# Performance üê¢ vs üêá

- **Lazy:** Fetch related data ONLY when accessed (can lead to N+1 problem).
- **Eager:** Fetch related data upfront (using JOINs) in a single query.

slides.title: Mapping Quiz
slides.quizQuestion: In an ORM, what does a Class strictly correspond to in the database?

slides.title: Relationships
slides.content:
# Associations üîó

Define how objects relate.

- One-to-One (`hasOne`)
- One-to-Many (`hasMany`)
- Many-to-Many (`belongsToMany`)

The ORM handles the foreign keys for you.

slides.title: Migrations
slides.content:
# Version Control for DB üìú

Code files that define schema changes.

`up()`: Create table `users`.
`down()`: Drop table `users`.

Allows teams to keep database schemas in sync.

slides.title: Seeding
slides.content:
# Dummy Data üå±

Populating the database with initial or test data.

`seed()`: Insert 100 fake users for testing.

slides.title: Active Record Pattern
slides.content:
# Logic in Model üß†

The model class contains both data AND database access logic.

`user = new User();`
`user.save();`

(Examples: Laravel Eloquent, Ruby on Rails).

slides.title: Data Mapper Pattern
slides.content:
# Separation of Concerns üß±

The model is just data (Entity). A separate Repository/Mapper handles DB operations.

`repo.save(user);`

(Examples: Hibernate, TypeORM, Doctrine).

slides.title: Pattern Quiz
slides.quizQuestion: Which pattern involves the object instance itself having methods to save/delete itself?

slides.title: Summary
slides.content:
# Recap: ORM üåâ

Code over SQL.

- **Mapping:** Class = Table.
- **Loading:** Lazy vs Eager.
- **Patterns:** Active Record vs Data Mapper.
- **Tools:** Migrations & Seeds.
